title: WOMEN’S SOCCER’S COMEBACK BID FALLS SHORT AT IDAHO
text:
WOMEN’S SOCCER’S COMEBACK BID FALLS SHORT AT IDAHO
The IU Indianapolis women's soccer team lost to Idaho 2-1 during their western road trip opener. After conceding two goals in the first half, the
Jaguars showed improved aggression in the second half, highlighted by a free kick goal from senior Cassie Rodriguez. Despite the loss, goalkeeper Emily Keck made five critical saves in 45 minutes, demonstrating resilience as the Jaguars pressed for an equalizer. The team continues to search for their first victory of the season, now standing at 0-3-1 as they prepare to face Montana next.
- Jaguars were outshot 17-9 overall, with a 8-6 edge in shots on goal for Idaho.
- Emily Keck recorded 5 saves in her half of play, while Cassie Rodriguez netted her 3rd career goal.
Despite the encouraging second-half performance, the Jaguars' struggles in the first half reveal ongoing challenges with their offense, particularly in creating scoring opportunities early in matches.State of Play
- The Jaguars improved their offensive intensity in the second half, generating multiple scoring chances.
- Head coach Chris Johnson emphasized the potential to build on the team's momentum despite the defeat.
IUPUI will face Montana on September 1 at 3:00 p.m. ET, aiming to capitalize on the positive aspects from their match against Idaho.Bottom Line
The Jaguars are showing resilience and fighting spirit, which could be a foundation for future success as they seek their first win of the season on the road.
